data.text: Lekker bike Amsterdam edition complete overhauled only thing left sort of original is the frame i bought the bike becouse it had a belt drive but it came with a 3 speed which ofcourse had to go now riding Shimano alfine 11 speed i liked the idea of less maintainence on the bike while on tour and before etc which it did my chain and cassette bike will only last about 12.000k if lucky my hub will outlast that anyday my belt needs a change every 30.000k or so hub only needs a oil change every 5000k so much longer lasting parts and less worrying about it

data.text: Keep it simple: titanium frame for comfort and lighness, 531 front forks for strength and positve steering, cable brakes for reliability, 700c wheels with heavy tyres etc etc. Tools to fix a problem on the side of the road. Seventy sux years of cycling in thirty seven countries - enjoy the journey!

data.author: Marcy Kelley

data.text: My first bikepacking bicycle 4 years ago was custom built on a Motobécane steel fat bike frame. 5" tires for snow, beach and rides in NJ Pine Barrens sugar sand roads and trails. Two years ago I built the yellow Tumbleweed steel framed bike with a Rohloff 14 speed gear box and 3" tires for rides with more road time such as a ride I took through Upper Ontario.
data.author: Edgar Maikisch

data.text: Here is my Tumbleweed.
data.author: Edgar Maikisch

data.text: Salsa Cutthroat. Light. Thick Carbon (durable), amazing geometry for an excellent sitting position.
data.author: Curtis Jones

data.text: Rivendell Hunqapillar, because it's a goanywheredoanythingforbigboys bike.
data.author: Marc Irwin

data.text: I love my Surly Long Haul Trucker which I found out just yesterday they no longer make￼ (except the disc version). I put 26 inch tires on it because that size makes it so much easier to find spokes, tubes, and/or tires when you are in the middle of nowhere. Especially when touring Asia.
data.author: Keith Gallinelli

data.text: Totally agree. I have a disc Trucker and a DeLuxe (S&S coupled) and much prefer the latter. My Discs always seem to get bent. in international transit. The DeLuxe has 36 spoke Ryde rims with tungsten carbide that are essentially wear-proof (at least for old me) using Paul’s MotoLite brakes and appropriate pads.
data.author: Richard Mitchell

data.text: And the Disc Trucker is actually a pretty substantial re-design compared to the older LHT as well. So, basically, they no longer make it at all anymore. That said, I am quite fond of my newer Disc Trucker.
data.author: Justin Stephen

data.text: I bought a 2020 disc trucker two weeks ago because my Kona was stolen. It wasn't on my radar, but now that I have it, I love it and look forward to the next big tour.
data.author: Rob Peterson

data.text: The LHT is no more, and many, many people are secretly balled up in the bathroom crying (myself included).
data.author: Ryan Tew

data.text: yeah me too. I think I’m gonna paint mine and re-decal it cause it is getting pretty banged up
data.author: Keith Gallinelli

data.text: I'd been just about to sell mine, when I heard that news. Now I'm gonna see how long a bike can really last
data.author: Jak Conrad

data.text: What color are you going to paint it? Post pictures if you do. I'd love to see!
data.author: Ryan Tew

data.text: it's like a collectable coin that doesn't necessarily have much more value than its face. Way more worth it to keep it than sell it!
data.author: Ryan Tew

data.text: I hope you get decades out of it, and tons of fun!
data.author: Ryan Tew

data.text: I found an NOS frame this year from a shop in Belleville Ontario. Building it up now. I even managed to find a set of NOS Velocity rims, (Made in Australia) SON hub in front, Sugino 3 X crank Brooks saddle etc. etc. Cant wait to get it on the road.
data.author: Andrew Cattani

data.text: I'm building up a 1985 Peugeot ATB right now. I just love the classic frames! That sounds like a great project! I'd like to see pictures, please!?
data.author: Ryan Tew

data.text: This is the Japanese built Peugeot I'm working on. Love it! People don't know what they're missing from a great older model bike that has flair!
data.author: Ryan Tew

data.text: Sure. As soon as I’m done i will be posting photos. Please post when you are finshed your project. I had a Peugeot 10 speed back then. It was stolen. I still think about that bike.

data.text: let us definitely keep in touch! Gracias!

data.author: Florian Koch

data.text: Deschutes by CoMotion is my current bike. I had previously been using Trek 520.
data.author: Dean Derek

data.text: Are you happy with the Deschutes? Also, are you using a Pinion, Rohloff, or deraileur? How is it for climbing?
data.author: Trevor Hughes

data.text: It has a derailleur. The 2X11 gear set up has the same range as my Trek 520 with 3X9 gear set up, with the 36-cog climbing gear. The geometry on this bike is so comfortable for me. I am not a great climber but do okay. I can keep this bike steady on hills down to about 3 mph or 4,8 kph. The Pangea is the Co Motion wish option, but the Deschutes hit the price point.
data.author: Dean Derek

data.text: Thanks for the info. Happy touring!
data.author: Trevor Hughes

data.text: A Koga World Traveller-S with Rohloff Speedhub and Gates carbon belt…minimal maintenance and virtually bulletproof!!

data.text: Kona Sutra SE. After lots of research and availability in Spain. I got myself a good tourer. Converted to electric complete with solar power and trailer.
data.author: Gary Hall

data.text: chapeau and tell me is it worthy these modification?
data.author: Mariglen Angjellari

data.text: I have had great pleasure building this bike and trailer. It’s a great achievement. The bike itself is a great bike and is a great touring bike. Yes by making the modifications I have added a lot more weight but the motor and performance of the battery makes up for that. I love the fact I can tour on an e-bike and that it’s as eco friendly as it can be. Charging from solar is just amazing.
data.author: Gary Hall

data.text: Raleigh Pardner 27 speed 26x4 FAT bike the last 3 years since August 2019. Total gear weight 15 lbs. Bike weight 50 lbs . I like it cause it'll go on any terrain snow, beach sand, dirt, pavement.

data.text: Salsa Marrakesh. It is heavy and slow, but extremely comfortable for long hours in the saddle. It is completely indestructable and suitable for road or gravel. Steel is real baby!

data.text: My Raleigh Sojourn rocks! It has a smooth feel and built for the long haul. I really love the disc brakes. Lots of great adventures and hopefully many more to come! ✌🚵‍♂️

data.text: , yeah, Sojourns kick ass. Don’t have one (I have a Raleigh Detour Deluxe) but the smoothest bike I ever test rode.

data.text: I also love my Raleigh M40 that I bought new in '94. Gave it to my son and now he's got the touring bug 👍

data.text: I built this one, Love the rear wheel stand and the way it handles solidly under a 4 full pannier load. Long framefit pump between the 2 chain&seatstay-top tubes.

data.text: Surly Pack Rat! Great load carrying capacity, steel, pretty good gearing. Need to customize but all around great bike out of the box.

Mike Parton

data.text: I built this up myself in 2007, a custom frame from Argos cycles then I meticulously chose each component, butterfly bars, Son front hub, Rohloff rear, Surly racks, Surly steel chairing, it's now completed 96,000km, money well spent.
data.author: Mark Wallis

data.text: As the frame maker had not used Rohloff specific drop-outs before I done a drawing for my own custom initialed ones, then had them laser cut from 6mm steel, then Argos cycles buffed them up before brazing in.

data.text: I bought a Co-Motion Americano ten years ago. They are made to fit, but I found one on a shelf at a dealer on sale that fit perfectly. I've put almost 40,000 miles on it and ridden it in China, Morocco, Egypt, Spain, France, Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Hungary, Austria, Germany, Liechtenstein, Switzerland, Luxemburg, Belgium, Holland, and Denmark. I tell people not to touch it because they don't know where it's been. It's my favorite bicycle ever.

data.text: Surly long haul trucker Since 2009 Have climbing gear inch of 18 ! Spin not grind up those long climbs
data.author: Bob Mack

data.text: Bacchetta Giro A20 touring recumbent , custom gearing so I have a low of 17.5" and a high of 93" 27 speed and short cranks @ 153 mm. Seat has been changed to a full mesh so that I sit in ,not on it. Why recumbent ? Aside from not being able to ride uprights due to nerve damage in both hands, the comfort factor on a recumbent surpasses any saddle you can sit on. As I sit and can not stand , I require a seat that is comfortable regardless of how many miles or hours I am sitting in it. I am looking straight ahead and no problem seeing drivers eyes or being seen. As to aerodynamics I am putting out less effort than a diamond frame bike rider does on flats , downhills and the uphills as well. However uphill's are a lot slower than a diamond frame rider will be able to climb, but I am still sitting in a comfortable seat and I do not walk any hills. Major difference is on a diamond frame bike I enjoy speed and on the recumbent I enjoy speed and comfort. What more could you ask for?

data.text: A 35-year-old Miyata 1000 with its timeless steel frame, a 15-year-old Cannondale touring model with its aluminum frame and great long-distance lines and a Bike Friday New World Tourist with drops circa 2016 because it travels great on planes and is durable as hell. Love them all.

data.text: 2019 Fuji Touring bought on EBay . It’s configured for touring and it’s built like a tank compared to my road and gravel bikes. It was one of the few touring bikes I could find in 2021. Very comfortable and solid.
